Writing Exponential Decay Functions

A car sells for $4,000 and loses \(\frac18\) of its value each year. Write a function that gives the car’s value, \(V(t)\), \(t\) years after it is sold. 

Since the car loses \(\frac18\) of its value each year, it keeps \(\frac78\) of its value from year to year, so the growth factor is \(\frac78\).

\(V(t)=4000 \cdot (\frac{7}{8})^t\)

Try It: Writing Exponential Decay Functions

A computer is purchased for $1,000 and loses \(\frac15\) of its value per year.

Write a function for the computer’s value, \(V(t)\), \(t\) years after it is purchased.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to write the exponential function: 

The starting amount is $1,000. The computer loses \(\frac15\) of its value each year, so it maintains \(\frac45\) of its value. The growth factor is \(\frac45\).

The function is then \(V(t)=1000 \cdot (\frac{4}{5})^t\).
